The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.  

The overall emergency response at the site is coordinated with the Clinton County Department of Emergency Services (DES), which is accomplished through the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the LEPC, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives to foster improved relations between Croda and local emergency response groups.  The site has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations.  


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Croda, Inc. believes strongly in continuous improvement and is always looking for opportunities to improve the safety of the plant.  Recommendations from Process Hazard Analyses, Incident Investigations, Compliance Audits, etc. are continuously incorporated into existing operations.

Future safety improvements include:

-Replacement of existing methyl chloride thermal oxidizer with a new regenerative thermal oxidizer
-Upgrades to fixed gas detection systems
-Expansion of safety instrumented functions on reactors that use ethylene oxide and propylene oxide
-Continuous evaluation and implementation of additional safeguards on reactor systems and bulk storage systems that utilize ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, methyl chloride, and epichlorohydrin

Croda Inc. facility in Mill Hall, PA:

Croda complies with OSHA PSM (29 CFR 1910.119) for all processes using ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, epichlorohydrin and methyl chloride. Croda takes its commitment to Process Safety seriously and demonstrates this with the investment of capital funds for safety improvements, such as the relocation of the EO rail car unloading to a remote area of the facility, installation of a safety instrumented system for EO storage, upgrades to relief valves, and for implementation of various PHA action items. Croda has rigorous programs in place for key elements of PSM, such as hazard assessment and management of change.

Croda utilizes many systems to control their process.  Some systems include one or more of the following:  vents, relief valves, check valves, scrubbers, oxidizers, manual shut-off valves, automatic shut-off valves, interlocks, excess flow valves, rupture disks, gas detection, alarms, and procedures.

Croda utilizes systems to mitigate the consequences.  Some systems include one or more of the following: dikes, enclosures, sprinkler systems, and deluge systems.  In addition, Croda has implemented other elements of the Prevention Program, and reviews these elements regularly for continuous improvement. These elements include:  

- Training
- Employee Participation
- Operating Procedures
- Mechanical Integrity
- Compliance Audits (most recently in October 2019)
- Accident Investigations
- Management of Change
- Safe Work Practices
- Contractor Safety


Five-Year Accident History

In the past five years, there have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

Executive Summary
EPA RMP Submission Document


Croda, Inc. seeks to provide a safe work environment for their employees as well as ensure the safety of individuals offsite.  In addition, Croda is aware of the potential environmental impacts of their operations and they are committed to minimizing the negative effects of their processes on the environment.


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Croda, Inc. has established Safety, Health, and Environmental policies that demonstrate a commitment from all levels of the company, starting with top management and cascading down through the Mill Hall site. Croda, Inc. has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.


Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled.

Croda, Inc. is a worldwide supplier for the personal care, household, pharmaceutical and manufacturing industries. The Mill Hall Site primarily produces ingredients for the personal care and pharmaceutical industries. 

There are four substances regulated by the EPA RMP Rule that are found above threshold quantities at the Mill Hall site, including:
-Ethylene Oxide (EPA designated toxic gas), stored in bulk up to 200,000 lbs.
-Propylene Oxide (EPA designated toxic liquid), stored in bulk up to 190,000 lbs.
-Methyl Chloride (EPA designated toxic gas), stored in bulk up to 89,000 lbs.
-Epichlorohydrin (EPA designated toxic liquid), stored in bulk up to 83,000 lbs.
